name: Somalia
currentCrisisSummary:
Somalia endures **converging structural crises**: protracted civil war stemming from **state collapse induced by Cold War legacies and neoliberal policies**; an entrenched al-Shabaab insurgency born from **failed 'War on Terror' interventions**; and **climate catastrophe** (droughts, floods) devastating livelihoods.

These dynamicsâ€”amplified by **geopolitical competition, external military interference, and predatory extraction** (illegal fishing, resource claims)â€”**produce chronic, widespread suffering**. Millions are displaced, public services have disintegrated, and **mass hunger recurs frequently**.

Aid efforts are hindered by insecurity and access constraints. Preventing repeated cycles of famine and displacement requires **Somali-led political solutions**, civilian protection, and large-scale, locally accountable **climate adaptation support alongside reparations for ecological damage**.

colonialRoot.legacy:
The crisis is rooted in the colonial partitioning of Somali-inhabited lands during the Scramble for Africa. Britain, Italy (and France in neighbouring territories) divided a culturally and linguistically cohesive people into separate political entities and imposed artificial borders that disrupted traditional economic and social systems.

The rushed post-colonial merger of former British and Italian territories in 1960 left a state with unresolved territorial, clan and governance tensions, a fragility that was later compounded by Cold War geopolitics and frequent external interventions.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberalism and State Collapse
historicalContext.description: The 1991 state collapse was preceded by a severe economic crisis and neoliberal intervention. During the 1980s, the indebted Siad Barre regime was forced to accept IMF-led Structural Adjustment Programmes. These policies enforced the deregulation of grain markets, leading to a flood of cheap imports that destroyed the livelihoods of local farmers. The mandated austerity and cuts to public services hollowed out the state's capacity and legitimacy, accelerating the social breakdown that culminated in civil war.

historicalContext.title: The Fragmented State
historicalContext.description: The collapse of central authority in 1991 unfolded in a Cold War context where Siad Barre's regime had been alternately supported by the USSR and the United States. The post-collapse period saw repeated external interventions that too often prioritised military objectives over Somali-led political settlement and resilient local governance.

historicalContext.title: The War on Terror and the Rise of Al-Shabaab
historicalContext.description: The post-9/11 'Global War on Terror' framework became a primary driver of the conflict. The 2006 US-backed Ethiopian invasion, designed to oust the popular Islamic Courts Union (ICU) which had brought relative stability to Mogadishu, is a key example. This intervention shattered a period of local governance and, in a classic case of blowback, catalysed the rise of the ICU's more radical youth wing, al-Shabaab. The subsequent decades of drone strikes, special forces operations, and proxy interventions have entrenched a cycle of violence, where external counter-terrorism priorities consistently undermine the potential for genuine, Somali-led political reconciliation.

historicalContext.title: Climate Change and Economic Exploitation
historicalContext.description:
Somalia is on the frontline of climate change: repeated failed rainy seasons, prolonged droughts and sudden floods have destroyed crops, killed livestock and deepened food insecurity. At the same time, the state's collapse opened space for illicit economic activity: illegal fishing by foreign fleets and documented toxic-waste dumping have eroded coastal livelihoods, while new competition for offshore resources risks generating fresh conflict dynamics.

These interlocking drivers â€” climate shocks, resource predation and political fragmentation â€” create what many analysts describe as ecological and economic injustice: the global north's emissions and commercial practices impose heavy costs on Somali communities.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: International responsibility is contested and partial. Human rights organisations, UN panels and investigative journalists have repeatedly documented abuses by state and non-state actors, including violations of humanitarian law in counter-insurgency operations and patterns of exploitation by transnational actors. Accountability mechanisms exist unevenly; strengthening independent documentation, protection of witnesses and Somali-centred transitional justice processes remains a priority.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands killed by **direct conflict and recurring famines (e.g., ~258k excess deaths in 2011)** driven by war, state collapse, and climate shocks.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 7 million people require aid due to the **compounded devastation of war, climate catastrophe, and economic predation.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: About 4.4 million face acute hunger (1.7M children malnourished), a direct result of **conflict disrupting farming, climate change causing crop failure, and economic collapse.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: About 3.5 million internally displaced, forced from homes by **internecine conflict and extreme weather events linked to global warming.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Approximately 714,000 refugees driven into neighbouring countries by **chronic violence and lack of basic survival means.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Public health system decimated by **decades of conflict and state failure**, leading to recurrent disease outbreaks.

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Over half the population lacks safe water due to **infrastructure destruction and state incapacity resulting from collapse and austerity.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Denied
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 3 million children denied education by **conflict destroying schools and displacing families.**

timeline.event: **Colonial Partition**: The British, Italian, and French empires carve up Somali-inhabited lands during the Scramble for Africa, creating artificial borders and political fragmentation.
**Independence & Unification**: Former British and Italian territories unite to form the Somali Republic, inheriting complex clan, regional and governance challenges.
**Siad Barre's Coup**: General Siad Barre seizes power, later aligning with the USSR; subsequent policies centralise power and sow grievances.
**Ogaden War**: Somalia's intervention in Ethiopia ends in military defeat and shifts Cold War alignments, accelerating militarisation.

**Structural Adjustment**: The indebted Barre regime accepts IMF-led austerity programmes. The deregulation of agriculture destroys rural livelihoods and deepens the economic crisis that precedes state collapse.
**State Collapse**: Barre's overthrow precipitates state collapse, civil war and the fragmentation of authority that creates long-term displacement and insecurity.

**International Intervention**: A US-led, UN-mandated humanitarian intervention ('Operation Restore Hope') withdraws after the 1993 Battle of Mogadishu; international engagement shifts repeatedly between humanitarian and military imperatives.

**US-Backed Invasion & Rise of Al-Shabaab**: A US-backed Ethiopian invasion ousts the Islamic Courts Union government in Mogadishu. The intervention shatters a period of relative stability and directly leads to the rise of al-Shabaab, the ICU's more radical youth wing.
**Famine & Drought**: A catastrophic famine and severe food insecurity event causes very high mortality and displacement, with later studies estimating around 258,000 excess deaths during 2010-2012.
**Climate Extremes & Renewed Crisis**: Repeated failed rainy seasons, severe drought followed by floods, and funding shortfalls drive renewed waves of displacement and acute food and nutrition needs.

donate.description: A Somali-led humanitarian and development organisation delivering cash, water and sanitation support and locally led resilience programmes.
Delivers emergency food and nutrition support across Somalia and to internally displaced and food-insecure populations.

advocacy: Push for increased, flexible climate finance and humanitarian funding that is channelled directly to Somali-led organisations and community networks.
Demand accountability for illegal fishing and toxic-waste dumping, and support coastal communities' rights to their marine resources.
Advocate for a shift from predominately militarised counter-terror strategies to Somali-led political processes, inclusive governance and investment in resilient livelihoods.
Support expanded humanitarian access, protection for civilians and strengthened monitoring of rights abuses by all armed actors.

reading.title: The World's Most Dangerous Place: Inside the Outlaw State of Somalia
reading.description: James Fergusson's reporting from post-collapse Somalia, exploring piracy, insurgency and local economies.

reading.title: Making Sense of Somali History: Volume 1
reading.description: Abdurahman Abdullahi (Baadiyow) offers a scholarly account of Somali history across pre-colonial, colonial and post-colonial periods.

reading.title: The Mayor of Mogadishu: A Story of Chaos and Redemption in the Ruins of Somalia
reading.description: Andrew Harding's biography of Mohamud 'Tarzan' Nur, tracing recent efforts at local governance and reconstruction.
